reasoning: The critique targets a reasonably central pillar of the essay’s optimism: that partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/moral trade could still yield a mostly-great future. If trade were generally infeasible, that would significantly weaken the essay’s most promising route (section 3), though not fully collapse the broader position (the essay already argues WAM-convergence is unlikely and discusses other blockers and scenarios). However, the critique’s core move—"ontological incompatibility" making trade unintelligible—overreaches: the essay’s trade notion primarily relies on shared physical resources, coordination, and contractability, not shared moral metaphysics of value or agency. The example given (deep ecologist treats commodification as intrinsic harm) is better read as ordinary value conflict/low resource-compatibility (which the essay already considers) rather than a failure to define transactions at all. Still, it is correct that sufficiently alien agents/values (taboos against trade, refusal to bargain, incompatible assumptions) could raise transaction costs and reduce realized gains from trade, so the critique provides a partially valid additional failure mode. It is fairly clear and focused, with little fluff, but it doesn’t substantively establish that such failures are likely or that costs “approach infinity,” so it only modestly weakens the targeted claim.
title: Radical value divergence may make moral trade conceptually impossible
